Column Comment.0: STANDARD METHOD SET IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a set or group ofstandard methods. Often, these would identify a method, consisting of severaldifferent steps, that are included in a typical analysis.
Column Comment.1: STANDARD METHOD SET IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a set or group ofstandard methods. Often, these would identify a method, consisting of severaldifferent steps, that are included in a typical analysis.
Column Comment.2: REFERENCE ANALYSIS MEASUREMENT TYPE: A list of valid measurement types.ANL QC VALID MEASURE lists which measurement types are valid for various typesof analysis, and what valid ranges for the values should be. In analysis detail tables,ensure that you have selected a measurement type that is appropriate for the type ofstudy.
Column Comment.3: VALID VALUE OBSERVATION NUMBER: A unique observation number for the validvalue.
Column Comment.4: ANALYSIS ACCURACY TYPE: The kind of accuracy that is indicated, such as theaccuracy of transcription from paper or spreadsheet into the database, or theaccuracy of the readings that a piece of equipment can make, or the impact of acontaminantinto the sample that may render results inaccurate.
Column Comment.5: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.6: AVERAGE RATIO VALUE: A number given to describe the average value of the ratiobetween these two samples.
Column Comment.7: AVERAGE VALUE: The average or single value assigned to this specification. If onlyone measure is provided, it should be stored here.
Column Comment.10: CALCULATION METHOD IDENTIFIER: Unique identifer for the method or formulaused to create a calculated or derived value.
Column Comment.11: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.12: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.13: MAXIMUM RATIO VALUE: The maximum value allowed for this ratio between thesetwo samples.
Column Comment.14: MAXIMUM VALUE: the maximum measured or observed value for this property.
Column Comment.17: MINIMUM RATIO VALUE: The minimum value allowed for this ratio between thesetwo samples.
Column Comment.18: MINUMUM VALUE: The minimum value assigned to this specification, such as thelowest, or starting temperature for a process.
Column Comment.21: ANALYSIS MISSING REPRESENTATION TYPE: A list of valid representations thatare used by labs when a measurement is missing because it is out of range. Usuallythis is the result of equipment limitations.
Column Comment.22: REFERENCE ANALYSIS NULL REPRESENTATION: a list of the valid values thatmay be used in the case where a reading or measurement or calculation was notprovided.
Column Comment.23: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.24: REFERENCE VALUE: the value of a reference point. For example the result may berelated to a specific luminosity, light intensity or other setting. Other reference values,such as pressures or temperatures that reference specifications are alsopermitted.
Column Comment.27: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.28: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.29: SUBSTANCE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a substance that can be describedeither chemically or in terms of composition. Elements, ions, isotopes, isomers,minerals, chemicals, solvents, production substances, hydrocarbons etc are all listed.Be advised that many applications and agencies may use the same term, but thedefinition and composition details may not be the same. Use the SUBSTANCE XREFtable to capture relationships between substances, such as similar substances.
Column Comment.30: VALID DESCRIPTION: Use this column to include additional narrative about a validvalue where necessary.
Column Comment.31: VALID VALUE TYPE: Use this column to list each valid value for the measurement,in cases where the value is text based.
Column Comment.32: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.33: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.34: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.35: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.36: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.37: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.38: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
